awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Transforming Residential Networks into Security Assets
awd_abstract_narration:
Residential computer networks are often insecure because they are unable to apply the best practices employed in corporate networks. The general public, who are often responsible for administering these networks, may lack the financial resources or computing expertise to deploy state-of-the-art network security systems. As a result, residential networks often offer little resistance to fraud and compromise. Further, these networks can enable infiltrations into corporate networks when users bring their mobile devices from the home to the corporate network. The rise of Internet-enabled embedded devices, such as household appliances and electrical power switches, can exacerbate these problems since a compromise can affect the residence's physical environment. To address these risks, this project will explore new mechanisms to send network traffic through security enforcement systems located outside the residence to carefully screen for attacks, both to traditional computers and to Internet-enabled embedded devices. The project's goal is to create new techniques that can improve security for the millions of residential computer networks in the United States.

The researchers will create a system to answer research questions surrounding the effectiveness, efficiency, performance, scalability, costs and incentives of delegating network security decisions to an external third-party security provider. Using an array of cloud-hosted security middleboxes, the researchers will measure the network latency and impact on bandwidth associated tunneling residential network traffic through these middleboxes before sending the traffic to its destination. The researchers will evaluate how new security mechanisms can be introduced at these middleboxes and how existing security protocols can be fortified in this model. The project will further explore how to detect and create custom security filters for Internet-enabled embedded devices to protect them attempts to exploit vulnerabilities that may be present on the devices. The researchers will explore generalizable models that can apply to embedded devices that have similar network interaction patterns to enable support for a large number of devices. Finally, the researchers will explore the potential for a new subfield of deployable residential network security. The researchers will examine which types of techniques are compatible with external third-party security providers and which techniques require an on-site security solution to be viable.

por.por_cntn:
Residential networks are typically created and configured by people without formal training in computer security. As a result, these networks typically lack the security measures present in enterprise networks managed by IT professionals. This work examined ways to improve the security of the networks by allowing experts or service providers to remotely manage the communication in the network.

In this project, we used a popular, consumer-grade wiress router and explored how we could use it to improve security. We explored how we could have it collaborate with a security control device running remotely, such as at a cloud data center, to determine whether communication patterns were legitimate or malicious. We examined the performance implications of this collaboration, particularly examining whether it would be too slow or otherwise negatively affect use. We found that most people would have a data center close enough to falicitate such an arrangement without negative impacts.

Knowing that we could use cloud control software to manage the security of a fleet of residential routers, we explored ways to improve the security of home users. We examined ways to improve the security with "Internet of Things" (IoT) devices, such as smart lightbulbs and power outlets. We created robust profiles of the types of traffic associated with devices and created rules to only allow such known-good behavior.

We examined how smartphones interact on residential networks, particularly to control IoT devices. We found that these devices could play a role in security networks by providing additional computing power to wireless routers. We found that the same profiling we performed on IoT devices could be used to secure communication associated with smartphone applications as well.

The project had intellectual merit in the field of computer network security, particularly through novel sensing capabilities. It advanced the state of the art in residential network security. One resulting publication received a conference's Best Paper Award for being the first to link activity on a smartphone with the network traffic associated with an IoT device. The project led to ten peer-reviewed publications.

The project had broader impacts that affected students at Worcester Polytechnic Institute (WPI), individuals from the Worcester Massachusetts community, and society as a whole. The project recruited undergraduate and graduate students at WPI to develop and evaluate new technologies. The Principal Investigator (PI) for the work shared the research with K-12 students and their parents through WPI's TouchTomorrow open house for people interested in learning about science and technology. The PI shared his work with students groups, such as WPI's Women in Cyber Security chapter.
